text: First reported arson attack at a Planned Parenthood clinic in Eugene, Oregon.
No fatalities reported were from an arson attack at the Cleveland's Concerned Women Clinic, but the incident resulted in clinic's closure.
Arson attack at reproductive rights activist Bill Baird's nonprofit abortion clinic in Hempstead, New York.

Dr. Hector Zevallos, an abortion clinic practioner, and his wife were kidnapped and held hostage for eight days; their captors threatened to kill them if President Reagan did not announce a legal end to abortion. Dr. Zevallos and his wife were released unharmed.
The Everett Washington Feminist Women's Health Center opened in August 1983 but closed only nine months later, after experiencing three separate arson attacks.
Firebombing destroys the Reproductive Care Center of Dover, Delaware.
Bombs were detonated outside the building housing the Hillcrest Clinic in Norfolk, Virginia, but the clinic was not damaged. A message signed "AOG" (Army of God) was found at the scene.
A Catholic priest was convicted of assulating two abortion clinic workers during a protest at the Women's Community Health Center.

In June 1984, two young men from Pensacola's First Assembly of God Church bombed the Ladies Center. Later that year on Christmas Day, the same two young men, James Simmons and Matthew Goldsby, bombed the clinic again at its new location.

Bomb explosion blew out building windows and tore a 16-square-foot hole in the wall of an Annapolis Planned Parenthood clinic. Two people were inside the building at the time of the attack, but no one was injured.

Forty-six abortion protesters were arrested for blocking the entrance to the Wheaton abortion clinic while brandishing graphic pictures and urging patients to change their minds. Two days later, a bomb was detonated at the clinic.

After the Wheaton clinic was the target of a weekend protest that resulted in 46 arrests, bombs were detonated at the clinic and at an office in the suburbs of Washington, DC. No injuries were reported.

James Simmons and Matthew Goldsby, who had already bombed the Ladies Center clinic in June, returned to the clinc's new location on Christmas Day in 1984 to bomb the premises and two nearby private practices that administered abortions.

Justice Harry Blackmun, who penned the Supreme Court's opinion legalizing abortion and received numerous death threats as a result, was shot at through the window of his home in 1985. No one was injured, however.
The Sacramento Planned Parenthood was partly destroyed by a World War II-vintage amphibious assault vehicle driven by the founder of Cobra, an anti-abortion group.

Four parcel bombs were mailed to Portland-area abortion and family planning clinics. Three of the four were disarmed before delivery, but one was delivered to the Women's Feminist Health Center in southeast Portland.

Eight members of the fundamentalist Bible Missionary Fellowship in Santee attempted to bomb the Family Planning Associates Medical Group on July 27. The gasoline bomb failed to detonate, however, when wind blew out the fuse.

More than 200 people were arrested at a protest for unborn children at the Cherry Hill Women’s Center in Cherry Hill, New Jersey. The protest was organized by Operation Rescue, a pro-life group based in Binghamton, New York.

The day Nebraska passed its parental-notification law, which required legal guardian consent for all abortions administed to minors, Dr. Carhart's farm was victim to an arson attack. No one was injured, but the fire destroyed his house and killed many of his animals. Carhart received a letter that said the fire was in retaliation for the abortions he had performed.
A gunman shot and injured two people at the Central Health Center for Women. One of the people shot was Ronald Catron, the owner of the building that houses the clinic.
Michael Griffin, an extreme anti-abortion activist, shot Dr. David gun three times in the back of the parking lot at the Pensacola clinc where he worked, killing him.
A fire destroyed a Missoula's women's clinic that has witnessed multiple anti-abortion protests. No one was injured, but damage was estimated at $250,000.

Shelley Shannon, an anti-abortion activist, shot Dr. George Tiller outside his abortion clinic in Wichita, Kansas, saying it is "the most holy, most righteous thing I've ever done." Dr. Tiller was killed years later, in 2009, by another anti-abortion extremist.

Dr. George Patterson, a woman’s health doctor in Mobile, Alabama, was shot to death behind a movie theater. Patterson owned and operated four abortion clinics in Florida and Alabama. His murder was two days after Kansas abortion provider Dr. George Tiller was shot.

Paul Hill, a former minister of two conservative Presbyterian denominations who long preached violence against abortion providers, shot and killed Dr. John Bayard Britton and his bodyguard escort James Barrett outside the Pensacola Ladies Center.

Gunman John Salvi opened fire at two abortion clinics in Brookline, Massachusetts, killing two female staff workers and wounding at least five other people. He was arrested the next day in Norfolk, Virginia, where he also opened fire on an abortion clinic.
After his deadly shooting spree in Brookline, Massachusetts, John Salvi traveled to the Hillcrest clinic in Norfolk, Virginia, where he was arrested after opening fire. No one was injured.
Three white separatists were convicted for multiple bombings and bank robberies in the Spokane area. One bombing was targeted at the Spokane Planned Parenthood.
Dr. Calvin Jackson was stabbed 15 times outside the Orleans Women's Clinic. The assailant was captured by police but served no jail time.
Two bombs, set to go off about an hour apart, damaged a suburban Atlanta abortion clinic and injured six people, including investigators and news reporters drawn to cover the first blast.
A man attempted to blow up the Family Planning Associates clinic in Bakersfield with a truck filled with tanks of propane and cans of gasoline, but there was no explosion, and no one was hurt.
An anti-abortion extremist was arrested on a felony arson charge for allegedly setting fire to the roof of the Medical Arts Center where a doctor who performed abortions worked.
A sniper shot at Dr. David Gandell's residence in Rochester, New York. Gandell is a well-known abortion provider.

Eric Robert Rudolph used a remote-control bomb to coordinate an attack outside of a Birmingham clinic, killing a security guard. He was also responsible for detonating bombs in Centennial Park, at a women's clinic, and at a gay nightclub in Atlanta in 1997.

Part of a militant group known as the Army of God, John Brockhoeft set fire to two local abortion clinics in 1985 and planted a pipe bomb at the temporary offices of one of them in 1987. He remained on the lam until arrested in Florida with bomb-making supplies in his car in May 1988.
Acid was dumped at the entrances to five Miami-area abortion clinics, causing minor injuries to three women and prompting an FBI investigation.
Dr. Barnett Slepian, who performed abortions, was shot to death by a sniper in his western New York home.
An explosive device went off outside Femcare clinic in Asheville, North Carolina, but caused no injuries and little damage, as it only partially detonated.
A mentally ill man who was sentenced to 30 months in 1996 for setting fire to an Albuquerque abortion clinic pleaded guilty to a second incident at a different clinic on May 1, 1999.

A Catholic priest drove his car into an abortion clinic, and then preceded to hit the building with an ax until the owner fired his gun twice to stop him. The attack came two days after federal approval of the abortion pill RU-486. No one was injured.
The WomanCare Center burned down from what police believed to be a firebomb attack. No one was hurt, but the building was destroyed, and the center is looking for a new location.
A suspicious fire damaged the Presidential Women's Center, where protesters have staged weekly demonstrations for more than a decade.

Paul Ross Evans, who admitted leaving a bomb outside an Austin women's clinic that performs abortions, was sentenced to 40 years in prison. "I never meant for anyone, except for the abortionists, to get hurt," Evans said.
Angry at his ex-girlfriend for planning to have an abortion at an Alberque clinic, a man and his friend proceeded to set fire to the clinic.
The man accused of driving into the entrance of the Planned Parenthood clinic in St. Paul told police that Jesus told him to do it.

Scott Roeder shot and killed Dr. George Tiller, one of the few doctors who performed late-term abortions, outside of Tiller's church. Tiller had been shot before by an anti-abortion extremist outside his abortion clinic in Wichita, Kansas, in 1993.
Donny Eugene Mower committed arson at the Madera Planned Parenthood clinic, causing more than $26,000 in damage.
The Planned Parenthood clinic in McKinney, Texas, which does not provide abortions, experienced an arson attack in 2012. There were no injuries.
A homeless man was sentenced to 10 years in federal prison Thursday for an arson attack against Pensacola's American Family Planning clinic.

Atlanta-area clinics specializing in women’s health services have witnessed three burglaries and now two fires. The first fire took place at a private OB-GYN office in the north Atlanta suburb of Gwinnett, and the second fire was at the Alpha Group GYN offices in Marietta.
A man convicted of starting a fire at a Planned Parenthood building in Grand Chute was sentenced to 11 years in prison.
A man took an ax to a Planned Parenthood clinic in Bloomington, Indiana, and then vandalized it with red paint. No one was injured.

Zachary Klundt was convicted of felony burglary, theft, and criminal mischief for ransacking All Families Healthcare. The clinic was the only facility in the area to provide first-trimester abortions. Clinic owner Susan Cahill closed her business following the break-in.
The New Orleans Fire Department investigated a morning car fire at the construction site for a new Planned Parenthood clinic in New Orleans.
The Planned Parenthood health center in Pullman, Washington, was set on fire and burned for several hours, causing extreme damage.

For the second time in weeks, a Planned Parenthood center in Thousand Oaks came under attack, this time by an arsonist or arsonists, who broke a window and splashed gasoline inside the clinic before igniting it.
An intruder used a hatchet to destroy computers, plumbing fixtures, phones, and medical equipment inside a Claremont Planned Parenthood clinic.
